tossups.question: Measurements of this quantity imply a transition zone where olivine changes between the phases found in the upper and lower mantle. Changes in this quantity for phenomena following a PKP path cause them to avoid a roughly thirty-six degree region opposite from their source. The boundaries between regions of Earth's interior are observed as discontinuities in this quantity. The time between primary and (*) secondary phenomena can be used to calculate the distance to an earthquake because this quantity is known for surface waves. Primary waves are named for having a higher value of this quantity than S-waves. For 10 points, name this quantity of seismic waves that can reach several thousand meters per second as they travel through rock.
tossups.answer: seismic wave velocity [or speed; accept speed of sound]

tossups.question: A character of this nationality who declares "I like guys to hurt me" plays "The Game" with her abusive Swedish boyfriend Lukas and has an on-again-off-again relationship with a boy whose mother cleans her house. An author with this nationality wrote the novels Conversations with Friends and Normal People. A poet of this self-identified nationality described how he once carried to his grandfather (*) "milk in a bottle / Corked sloppily with paper" in a poem where he performs the title action "between my finger and my thumb" with a "squat pen." That same poet who identified with this nationality opened Death of a Naturalist with "Digging." For 10 points, name this nationality of Sally Rooney and Beowulf translator Seamus Heaney.
tossups.answer: Irish [do not accept or prompt on “United Kingdom” or “U.K.”] (Heaney was born in Northern Ireland but insisted on his Irish nationality.)

tossups.question: Description acceptable. Investors concerned about this event were told to "put their hearts at ease" after a negotiation with "Jock the Sock" MacLehose. The date for this event was called "as good as forever" in an 1898 "extension" negotiated by Claude Maxwell MacDonald. A framework negotiated prior to this event was violated in the Causeway Bay Books scandal. 60,000 people emigrated to Vancouver prior to this event after its date was finalized in a (*) 1984 agreement signed by Margaret Thatcher. The Basic Law was written seven years prior to this event and enforceable for fifty years after this event as per the One Country, Two Systems policy. For 10 points, name this July 1997 event where a former British Asian colony was returned to control by Beijing.
tossups.answer: the British handover of Hong Kong in 1997 [accept anything involving the British giving up control of Hong Kong to the Chinese]

tossups.question: These people originated a ritual gesture in which they raised their hands with the palm facing outward and thumb extended, as they parted their fingers between the middle and ring fingers. One of these people accused Hannah of being drunk before asking God to grant her petition for a child. In the "documentary hypothesis," a source named after these people is thought to make up most of (*) Leviticus. The head of these people wore the ceremonial ephod ("AE-fod"), which was used for divination with the Urim ("yoo-REEM") and Thummim ("THOOM-mim"). The common Jewish surname "Cohen" literally refers to these people. The first men to be appointed as these people were Aaron and his sons. For 10 points, name these people who led Jewish worship and sacrifices at the Temple in Jerusalem.
tossups.answer: Jewish priests [or kohanim before "Cohen" is read; accept high priest or kohen gadol; accept priestly blessing; accept Priestly source; prompt on Jews or Israelites; prompt on clergy or religious officials; prompt on Levites; do not accept "rabbi"]

tossups.question: The Knudsen number is a ratio between characteristic measures of this value for a system and determines whether continuum mechanics can be used. A lecture suggesting that "there's plenty of room" for science when this value is small was given by Richard Feynman at Caltech. The zero-point energy for a 1D particle in a box is inversely proportional to the square of this value for the box. Intermediate magnitudes for this value indicate a system is (*) mesoscale. Gravity stops behaving classically as this value approaches a limit named for Planck and must be described with quantum mechanics instead. For 10 points, name this value that describes how large something is with units of meters.
tossups.answer: length [or distance; accept length scale; accept answers indicating what size something is; accept mean free path or path length; accept scale before "mesoscale"; prompt on the bottom]

tossups.question: In 2003, this American recruited the biologist Martin Nowak to head a new facility that he established. An interview about this American led to a spate of sarcastic Google reviews for a Pizza Express in Woking, England. This transhumanist funded the Program for Evolutionary Dynamics at Harvard and owned a house on East 71st Street that was one of the largest in Manhattan. Alexander (*) Acosta resigned his post as Secretary of Labor after the lenient deal he gave this man, whose "Black Book" of contacts included Prince Andrew. This man's private plane was dubbed the “Lolita Express.” For 10 points, name this hedge fund manager and sex abuser who died in prison in 2019.
tossups.answer: Jeffrey Epstein

tossups.question: An artist from this country painted a bird's nest being examined by a young couple and their dog in an idyllic landscape titled The Robber of the Sparrow's Nest. In a painting from this country, painted as a commercial advertisement, a young man helps a woman in green stockings enter the title establishment which is filled with nude portraits. In that work, a man (*) boxes up a portrait of this country's king. An artist from this country may have depicted the birthplace of Aphrodite in a painting whose central crowd of couples are either departing or sailing towards the title island. For 10 points, name this home country of the painter of the first fête galante, The Embarkation for Cythera, Jean-Antoine Watteau.
tossups.answer: France [or French Republic or République française]

tossups.question: Suffragist Adella Hunt Logan tragically jumped from the top floor of a building in this city; that building was part of an institution fundraised for by Olivia America Davidson that was modeled on a similar one in Hampton, Virginia. Chief Anderson taught a group of pilots training at this city's Moton Field. 500 textile dyes were developed during World War II in this city at an institution founded by the man who gave the 1895 (*) "Atlanta Exposition Speech." Hundreds of uses for peanuts were developed by a chemist working in this city, George Washington Carver. Black men in this city were unknowingly subjected to an experiment on untreated syphilis. For 10 points, name this Alabama city whose Institute was founded by Booker T. Washington.
tossups.answer: Tuskegee, Alabama [accept Tuskegee University or Tuskegee Institute]

tossups.question: The protagonist of this book is haunted by the image of "injecting blood into the veins of society." During a chapter of this book set in the punk era, kids hang around a restaurant named Kansas. A child in this book tells God about her educational comics on dialectical materialism. In this book, a woman hides two posters by sewing them into her husband's suit; one of those is a poster of Kim Wilde. Its protagonist laments the death of her uncle (*) Anoosh, and is expelled upon mentioning imprisonment in her Religion class. This memoir's first volume, subtitled "The Story of a Childhood," ends when the fourteen-year-old author leaves revolutionary Iran. For 10 points, name this graphic novel memoir by Marjane Satrapi.
tossups.answer: Persepolis: The Story of a Childhood [accept answers like Persepolis 1: The Story of a Childhood or Persepolis 2: The Story of a Return]

tossups.question: This book rejects the idea that men are naturally superior to women and cites the Amazons to argue that women can hold authority. An earlier section of the book lays out nineteen new "natural laws," which, it argues, can be summarized in the dictum "Do not that to another, which thou wouldst not have done to thy selfe." The introduction of this text asserts that "life is but a motion of limbs" and proclaims that art can create an (*) "Artificial Man." The pope is one of the four sources of the "Kingdom of Darkness" that titles its final section. This book describes a state of "war of every man against every man" in societies without an absolute monarch. For 10 points, name this work of political philosophy by Thomas Hobbes.
tossups.answer: Leviathan: Or, The Matter, Form, and Power of a Commonwealth, Ecclesiastical and Civil

tossups.question: These substances can be progressively replaced during activation of a metal-organic framework as a milder alternative to treatment with supercritical CO2. The efficacy of these substances can be measured using the energy required to separate individual molecules from their neighbors, a metric named for Joel Hildebrand. A conical piece of lab equipment is used to move organic molecules from one of these substances to another. (*) Polar aprotic examples of these substances have higher dielectric constants and cannot serve as hydrogen bond donors. Immersion in these substances allows all inputs to a reaction to exist in the aqueous phase. For 10 points, name these substances which can dissolve salts and other compounds to form solutions.
tossups.answer: solvents [prompt on solutions; prompt on liquids or liquid-liquid extraction; prompt on guest molecules]

tossups.question: Description acceptable. In retribution for this event, Wael Zwaiter was symbolically shot 11 times. This event, which prompted the formation of Committee X ("ex"), was predicted ahead of time in Georg Sieber's "Situation 21." A Moroccan waiter was killed in Lillehammer after being mistaken for a member of this event's perpetrators, several of whom were released following the hijacking of Lufthansa Flight 615. NBC reporter Jim McKay somberly stated "they're all gone" following the failed (*) police raid that ended this event. Prime Minister Golda Meir authorized Operation Wrath of God to assassinate the Black September perpetrators of this event. For 10 points, name this event in which Israeli athletes were killed by Palestinian terrorists in a Bavarian city.
tossups.answer: Munich massacre [or the massacre at the 1972 Summer Olympics; or massacre at the games of the 20th Olympiad; accept anything involving a Palestinian hostage taking or massacre of Israelis during the 1972 Summer Olympics at Munich (either acceptable); prompt on Black September attack until read]

tossups.question: To inquire about the sales of a novel, this author sent a telegram consisting of a question mark, to which his publisher replied with an exclamation mark. The drowning of this author's daughter Léopoldine inspired him to pen the poetry collection The Contemplations while exiled in Guernsey, where he set Gilliatt's ("ZHEE-lee-AT’s”) fight with an octopus. This author's line, "this will kill that," referring to the printing press and (*) architecture, is said by a villainous archdeacon. A novel by this author includes lengthy digressions on the Battle of Waterloo and Paris's sewers, which the protagonist uses to escape while carrying the body of Marius, the lover of Cosette. For 10 points, name this author who created Jean Valjean in Les Miserables.
tossups.answer: Victor Hugo [or Victor Marie Hugo]

tossups.question: This woman bites on a blade of grass while reading Whitman in a Dave Cicero photo, one of many of her posed with a book. In photographs taken shortly before this person's death, she wears a wool knit sweater while frolicking along the Santa Monica beach. A screen print diptych made in the manner of a Byzantine icon juxtaposes bright pink images of this woman with black and white images. The best-known (*) still of this person was taken by Sam Shaw after her character exits a movie theater alongside Tom Ewell on Lexington Avenue in a Billy Wilder film. This woman was the subject of the Flying Skirt photo and a series of prints by Andy Warhol. For 10 points, name this star of The Seven Year Itch and Gentlemen Prefer Blondes.
tossups.answer: Marilyn Monroe [or Norma Jeane Mortenson]

tossups.question: Ovid's Fasti says that the month of February was sacred to this deity, as a February 1st festival was dedicated to this deity's "Sospita" aspect. Tibullus suggests that either this deity or a spirit of the same name was the feminine counterpart of the male "genius." An epithet of this deity possibly derived from a word for "warning" was connected to an incident in which this deity's sacred (*) geese warned a general of Brennus' approaching Gauls. When Turnus' raid on the Trojan fortress goes south, this deity saves him from death. A storm created by this deity drives Dido and Aeneas into a cave. She was often addressed as Regina, or "Queen." For 10 points, name this Roman goddess of childbirth and marriage, whose Greek equivalent was Hera.
tossups.answer: Juno [prompt on Hera before mention with "what is her Roman name?"]

tossups.question: Irving B. Weiner's textbook on this procedure surveys the much-derided "ouija ("wee-jee") board" method of conducting it. In the 1970s, John Exner standardized the five separate scoring systems that developed after the early death of this procedure's namesake. The R-PAS guidelines for assessing results in this system accounts for traits like French subjects being more likely to identify chameleons. Unlike the MMPI, this assessment is not self-reported. This assessment consists of (*) ten items, two of which combine gray, black and other colors; all ten items are intended to be an ambiguous stimulus to which patients respond. For 10 points, name this psychological test where patients are asked to describe images in ink blots.
tossups.answer: Rorschach inkblot test [or Rorschach inkblot method; prompt on Form Interpretation Test; prompt on inkblot test before the end]

tossups.question: This king was sometimes joined in battle by his wife Hypsicratea (“HIP-suh-CRAHT-ee-ah”), who donned men's clothes. This man supposedly inherited a capital city from the final ruler of the Spartocid dynasty, Paerisades (“puh-RISS-a-dees”) V. Conrad Gessner titled a 1555 book on linguistics after this polyglot who Pliny the Elder claimed could speak the 22 different languages of the kingdoms he ruled. This king massacred 80,000 troops on advice from his court philosopher Metrodoros "The Roman-Hater" in the (*) Asiatic Vespers. Later, this king and his son-in-law Tigranes were defeated in 66 BCE by forces led by Pompey. This king supposedly consumed small doses of poison to build up immunity. For 10 points, name this "Great" king of Pontus.
tossups.answer: Mithridates VI [or Mithradates VI Eupator Dionysus; or Mithridates the Great; prompt on the Poison King]

tossups.question: In this state, a man offers Judge Lynch seventeen hundred dollars and a watch to save Tennessee's life. In another story, travelers in this state listen to "the Innocent" pronounce "Achilles" as "Ash-heels" while retelling the Iliad. Those stories were first published in a magazine published in this state and called the Overland Monthly. A man who dies in this state pencils his epitaph onto a two of (*) clubs. While traveling to the town of Sandy Bar in this state, John Oakhurst commits suicide when caught in a snowstorm. Kentuck fails to save a boy named Luck from a flash flood in this state's town of Roaring Camp. For 10 points, name this state, the setting of "The Outcasts of Poker Flat" and many of Bret Harte's Gold Rush stories.
tossups.answer: California

tossups.question: The output of this technique provides the more common name for glycated hemoglobin, or hemoglobin A1c. A solvent delivery system is used in a form of this technique which runs in isocratic or gradient modes depending on the composition of its solvent, and is regularly run in tandem with mass spectrometry in proteinomics. Several washes of imidazole may be used in a form of this technique used to (*) isolate proteins designed to contain poly-his tags. This technique's output is often separated into fractions of the eluent which may be analyzed separately. In this technique, a mobile phase carries mixtures of interest past a stationary phase. For 10 points, name this separation technique named for its initial use in separating colored plant pigments.
tossups.answer: chromatography [accept specific forms such as ion exchange chromatography or high-pressure liquid chromatography; accept HPLC]

tossups.question: The slow notes (read slowly) E, high G-sharp, F that open this composer's second symphony gave it the nickname "The Bell." The main cadenza of this composer's violin concerto is introduced by a dialogue of rapid arpeggios between the clarinet and solo violin. That D minor concerto by this composer was dedicated to and premiered by David Oistrakh. This composer wrote a five-movement suite extracted from incidental music to the play Masquerade. A ballet by this composer includes a piece that opens with a xylophone playing stabbing eighth-note F-sharps. The oft-excerpted (*) Adagio from another ballet by this composer depicts the escape of Phrygia and the title slave, Spartacus. For 10 points, name this Armenian composer whose Gayane (gah-yah-NAY) includes the "Sabre Dance."
tossups.answer: Aram Khachaturian [accept Aram Ilyich Khachaturian]

tossups.question: Description acceptable. Sriran Kosuri adapted the Octant platform for a high-throughput solution to this task. The companies Puritan and Copan provide nearly 100% of a key piece of wooden equipment for performing this task. An organization led by Robert Redfield initially blocked US institutions from creating their own methods for performing this task. An Israeli research team developed a way to perform this task in (*) one minute by using terahertz spectroscopy. Ellume now sells at-home kits for this task that have a lower sensitivity than ones based on PCR. The Defense Production Act helped keep up supplies of nasopharyngeal swabs needed for this task. For 10 points, name this procedure that determines if people are infected with a certain pandemic virus.
tossups.answer: coronavirus testing [accept descriptive answers involving both a testing process and coronavirus; accept COVID-19 or Sars-CoV-2 in place of coronavirus; prompt on partial answers; prompt on PCR testing or polymerase chain reaction reaction; prompt on virus testing; prompt on swabbing]

bonuses.leadin: A 1974 book by this author examines how people such as Brett Hauser, a supermarket box boy, do their jobs. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Studs Terkel [or Louis Terkel]
oral history
Soviet Invasion of Afghanistan [or Soviet-Afghan War; prompt on the Cold War]
parts: Identify this historian and Chicago-area radio host behind books like Working and The Good War.

Terkel's Working is this type of history, which collects verbatim interviews from people and presents them directly in the text. This type of history has been widely adopted by websites to revisit pop culture events.

Another prominent oral historian, Svetlana Alexievich, interviewed participants in this conflict for her book Boys in Zinc. The US boycotted the 1980 Summer Olympics in opposition to one side in this war.

bonuses.leadin: Hypohidrosis refers to an inability to release normal amounts of this fluid, which is primarily secreted by apocrine and eccrine glands. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: sweat [or sweating; prompt on perspiration or perspirant]
chloride [or Cl-; do not accept or prompt on chlorine]
capsaicin
parts: Identify this fluid which is released in order to control body temperature. It can accumulate on the forehead or under the armpits during stressful situations.
One way to diagnose cystic fibrosis is to measure for elevated amounts of this ion in one's sweat because the defective CFTR channels impair the reabsorption of this ion and sodium.

The binding of this chemical compound to TRPV1 receptors leads to gustatory sweating as a thermoregulatory response. Like lidocaine, a patch containing this compound may be used to control peripheral neuropathy.

bonuses.leadin: The critic Morelli poses the challenge of writing a novel without conventional psychology in this novel's 62nd chapter, which inspired the author to write 62: A Model Kit. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Hopscotch [or Rayuela]
Julio Cortázar [or Julio Florencio Cortázar]
Mario Vargas Llosa [or Jorge Mario Pedro Vargas Llosa, 1st Marquess of Vargas Llosa; prompt on Llosa]
parts: Name this stream-of-consciousness novel that follows characters such as Talita and Horatio Oliveira, the latter of whom is searching for La Maga. It has 99 expendable chapters.
Hopscotch was written by this Argentine author of the story "The Axolotl."

According to scholarly consensus, the Latin American Boom of the 1960s and 70s either began with the publication of Hopscotch or with this author's novel The Time of the Hero. This Peruvian right-winger wrote Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter.

bonuses.leadin: A society of this name formed in the 18th century likely derived its name from the unusual garments worn by Bishop Benjamin Stillingfleet. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: bluestockings [or Bluestocking Society; or Bluestocking Circle]
salons [accept cabinet or réduit or ruelle or alcôve]
Jacques Necker
parts: Identify this now-derisive term for a group of intellectual women such as Hester Thrale and Elizabeth Montagu.
Montagu hosted one of these intellectual gatherings. Girondins discussed politics at one of these regular gatherings hosted at the home of Madame Roland.

One influential salon was hosted by the wife of this Swiss-born Minister of Finance to Louis XVI (16), whose widely-read 1781 report on the French budget grossly oversold the country's fiscal solvency.

bonuses.leadin: Economist Claudia Goldin found that the curve for this quantity for women first falls, then rises after industrialization, creating a U-shape. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: labor force participation rate [or LFPR; or economic activity rate; do not accept "unemployment rate"]
capital [accept human capital or Das Kapital]
pink [accept pink tax or pink-collar jobs]
parts: Name this stat, the total number of people in the workforce or looking for work divided by the total number of potential workers.
Goldin argued that the "high school movement" in the US led to a century of increasing the "human" form of this factor of production that also titles a Karl Marx book.

Goldin has also written about women's over-representation in low-paying, caregiving jobs described by this adjective. A "tax" named for this adjective refers to the extra price attached to products marketed to women.

bonuses.leadin: This substance permeates the intergalactic space, the interstellar space, and the interplanetary space. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: cosmic dust [or space dust; accept intergalactic, interstellar, or interplanetary dust; prompt on interstellar medium or ISM]
ecliptic plane [prompt on answers indicating the rotational plane of Earth or the rotational plane of the planets]
Spitzer Space Telescope [accept Spitzer Warm Mission; prompt on Space Infrared Telescope Facility or SIRTF]
parts: Name this substance whose many fine particles absorb and scatter visible light.
Within our solar system, dust produces a dim light over the horizon along this plane, which defines the zodiac constellations. This plane is inclined 23.4 degrees from the axis of the Earth.

This telescope can probe objects surrounded by dense dust because IR light can penetrate through. This telescope trails Earth in a heliocentric orbit to avoid accidentally heating up, and it entered its productive "warm" period after running out of coolant.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about jazz singer Sarah Vaughan, for 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: soul [accept "Body and Soul"; accept "Heart and Soul"]
Charlie Parker Jr.
"Send in the Clowns"
parts: Vaughan was discovered at the Apollo singing a song titled for the "Body" and this other entity. Hoagy Carmichael and Frank Loesser wrote a famous standard titled for "Heart" and this entity.
Vaughan helped pioneer bebop as part of the Earl Hines Big Band, which included this bebop saxophonist who was nicknamed “Bird.” This musician wrote standards such as “Ornithology” and “Ko-Ko.”
Vaughan sang a three-octave version of this song, which opens "Isn't it rich? / Are we a pair?". This song, a signature of Judy Collins, comes from Act II of Stephen Sondheim's A Little Night Music.

bonuses.leadin: An eight-year-old boy puts on a puppet show in this author's story "Just Right." For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Zadie Smith [or Sadie Smith]
Granta
Nobel Prize in Literature [prompt on Nobel Prize]
parts: Name this author who wrote about Samad Iqbal and Archie Jones in her novel White Teeth.

"Just Right" was published in a 2013 issue of this literary magazine that publishes a list of the best young British novelists every decade. It has published essays by authors of color about "How to Write About Africa" and "How to Write About Pakistan."
Olga Tokarczuk, who has been published by Granta, won this prize in 2018 for her novel Drive Your Plow Over the Bones of the Dead. Poet Louise Glück won this prize in 2020.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, identify the following about the legacy of Charles F. Kettering.
answers_sanitized: lead [or Pb]

hole in the ozone layer [or Antarctic hole in the ozone layer; the depletion of the ozone layer; or thinning of the ozone layer; prompt on air pollution; prompt on air quality; prompt on climate change on the grounds that fixing the ozone layer helps reduce climate change; prompt on just ozone layer] (the invention was freon)
paint [or lacquer; or automotive paint; or mineral paint; prompt on pigments]
parts: While at General Motors, Kettering came up with adding this toxic substance to gasoline. Pipes made from this element may have contributed to the fall of the Roman Empire.
Another Kettering invention contributed to this problem, which was addressed after Kettering's death by the 1987 Montreal Protocol.
More positively, Kettering invented a form of this stuff called Duco for the DuPont company. In fiction, Silas Lapham makes his fortune manufacturing this stuff.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about depictions of Adam and Eve, for 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Brueghel [accept Jan Brueghel the Elder]
Ghent Altarpiece [accept Adoration of the Mystic Lamb]
Hieronymous Bosch [or Jheronimus Bosch or Joen Bosch or Joen van Aken or Jheronimus van Aken]
parts: An artist from this family painted animals and flowers for The Garden of Eden with the Fall of Man, in which his collaborator Peter Paul Rubens painted Adam and Eve. That same artist from this family also worked with Rubens on The Five Senses.

Adam and Eve flank two angels playing instruments and face towards the center from the extremes of this work. Many groups of people admiringly gather around a lamb bleeding into a grail in another section of this work.
God grabs Eve's wrist as Adam wakes up and watches in the left panel of this artist's triptych The Garden of Earthly Delights.

bonuses.leadin: This religion criticizes what it calls "race-mixing," since it believes that each "race" has a separate paradise. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Fǎlún Gōng [or Fǎlún Dàfǎ]
The Epoch Times [accept Epoch Media Group]
aliens [or extraterrestrials; accept obvious synonyms]
parts: Name this Chinese religion founded by Lǐ Hóngzhì, which includes breathing exercises called qìgōng (“chee-gong”). It also operates the Shen Yun performance troupe.

A 2021 Atlantic article describes how employees of this Fǎlún Gōng-operated, anti-communist media outlet were encouraged to spend 15 minutes every six hours to close their eyes and "send forth righteous thoughts."
Lǐ Hóngzhì claimed that these beings introduced modern technology to control humans. According to Scientology, one of these beings named Xenu formerly ruled the Earth.

bonuses.leadin: Nationalists from this country credited the medieval folk hero, Prince Madoc (“MAD-ahk”), with discovering America three hundred years before Columbus. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Wales [prompt on United Kingdom or Great Britain; do not accept or prompt on "England"]
a cauldron [prompt on pot or kettle]
salmon [accept salmon of knowledge]
parts: Name this country whose myths, including a prose narrative made up of four "branches," were translated into English by Lady Charlotte Guest.

The Welsh poet Taliesin (“ta-lee-ESH-in”) tended one of these objects for a year as a servant for Ceridwen (“CARE-id-wen”). In another myth, Efnisien (“eff-NISH-en”) destroys one of these objects that can revive the dead.
The myth about Taliesin and the Cauldron of Inspiration is similar to the tale of Finn MacCool, who gains wisdom from eating a drop of the fat of one of these fish.

bonuses.leadin: This city appears in a two-word term originated in an Atlantic Monthly essay which became the first chapter of Elsie Venner. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Boston, Massachusetts [accept Boston Brahmins]
Lowell family [accept Robert Lowell; accept James Russell Lowell]
Oliver Wendell Holmes Sr.
parts: "Elite" northeastern families like the Cabots and Thayers are referred to as this city's "Brahmins." Part 2 of The Sound and the Fury opens at Harvard in this city's suburb of Cambridge.

One member of this "Brahmin" literary family wrote the Confessional poetry collection Life-Studies. An earlier member of this family said that Edgar Allan Poe was "two-fifths genius, three-fifths sheer fudge" in A Fable for Critics.
This physician coined "anesthesia" and "Boston Brahmin." He also wrote "The Deacon's Masterpiece."

bonuses.leadin: The traditional indigo-dyed clothes of these people often stained their skin blue, leading to their nickname of "Blue People." For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Tuareg [or Twareg; Touareg]
Ibn Khaldun [or Abū Zayd 'Abd ar-Raḥmān ibn Muḥammad ibn Khaldūn al-Ḥaḍramī; prompt on Khaldun]
Senegal [or Republic of Senegal; accept Senegal River]
parts: Identify these people whose Kel Owey clan controlled much of northern Niger in the 19th century. Timbuktu was captured in a rebellion named for these Berber people that broke out in 2012.
Berber peoples like the Tuareg constructed mausoleums called jedars. Some early evidence of the jedars comes from the Prolegomena of this well-traveled Tunisian historian of the 14th century.
Tuareg camel caravans often carried gold mined along a river of this name, which shares its name with a modern-day country with a capital at Dakar.

bonuses.leadin: A team of Canadian scientists led by Eric Hessels recently measured this particle's radius as 0.833 femtometers, confirming an earlier measurement by Randolf Pohl. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: protons
Lamb shift
magnetic field [or B field]
parts: Identify this particle. The number of these particles in the nucleus of an atom determines an element's atomic number.
Hessels' team used this energy difference to measure the proton's radius. This contributor to the fine structure is the energy difference between the 2S and 2P states in the hydrogen atom.
Another contributor to the fine structure is the Zeeman effect, which is a splitting of spectral lines in the presence of one of these entities.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about world music's influence on American minimalist La Monte Young, for 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: China [or People's Republic of China; or PRC] [or (The second composer is Tan Dun.)
India [or Republic of India]
percussion instruments [accept drums, gongs, or other specific percussion instruments]
parts: Young was inspired by the sounds of telephone poles for one of a set of four "dreams" of this country. A composer from this country incorporates instruments made of paper, stones, and water into his pieces, such as Water Concerto.
Young studied under a musician from this country, Pandit Pran Nath, whose droning tanpura music inspired Young's later music. Sitars are used in this country's music.
Young drew inspiration from Chatur Lal, a tabla player. The tabla is an instrument from this family, which contains most instruments that make up the gamelan ensemble.

bonuses.leadin: Mother Wolff decides to steal the title object from Krüger to sell to Wulkow in this author's play The Beaver Coat. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Gerhart Hauptmann
fairies [accept sprites] (the Shakespeare play is A Midsummer Night's Dream)
Bertolt Brecht [or Eugen Berthold Friedrich Brecht]
parts: Name this German dramatist who wrote about a riot led by Moritz Jaeger against the harsh policies of Dreissiger in his play The Weavers.

In Hauptmann's play The Sunken Bell, Heinrich completes a bell which is to be hung on a mountain inhabited by these characters. Mob and Cobweb are two of these beings in a Shakespeare comedy set in Athens.
An unrelated author named Elisabeth Hauptmann may have worked with this author on his "play with music" The Threepenny Opera. He also wrote Mother Courage and Her Children.

bonuses.leadin: These trees are some of the rare invasive species that come from Australia. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: eucalyptus trees [or eucalypti; or gum trees; or stringybark trees; prompt on Myrtaceae]
Portugal [or Portuguese Republic; or República Portuguesa]
Bilbao [or Bilbo] (The building is the Guggenheim Museum Bilbao.)
parts: Identify these oil-producing trees widely planted throughout Europe as a "wonder crop" in the 19th century. In Europe, they lack natural predators like possums and koalas.
Eucalyptus plantations in this country contribute to fires in its pinhal interior. This Iberian country also controls the autonomous regions of the Azores and Madeira.

Rosendo Salvado introduced eucalyptus trees into Biscay, whose capital is this city. This European city names an "effect" where cultural investments reap economic gain, a reference to a glass, titanium and limestone building on its Nervión River.

bonuses.leadin: People who brought vinyl records with them to this event were given a special discounted ticket price. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Disco Demolition Night
Chicago
Studio 54 [accept Studio 54 Radio]
parts: Name this July 1979 event in which music popularized by Saturday Night Fever was burned at a baseball stadium. 39 people were arrested following this event.
Disco Demolition Night took place in this Midwestern city's Comiskey Park. Barack Obama's presidential library will be located in this city, also home to Wrigley Field.
This exclusive Manhattan nightclub reached its peak during the disco era. Steve Rubell co-owned this nightclub which now lends its name to a SiriusXM radio station.

bonuses.leadin: Ramping this quantity both up and down produces a symmetric response that appears somewhat duck-like. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: voltage [or reduction potential; accept voltammograms, cyclic voltammetry, or overpotential]
redox [or reduction-oxidation; prompt on reduction or oxidation]
mercury [or Hg; accept dropping mercury electrode, mercury(I) chloride]
parts: Name this quantity, which is measured against a reference like the ferrocene/ferrocenium couple. Inefficiencies produce an "over" value of this quantity, which must be supplied to initiate the reaction.
Voltammetry analyzes this class of reaction in which electrons are transferred between molecules in two half-reactions.
Polarography is effectively linear-sweep voltammetry using electrodes made of this element. The formation of this element's unusually diatomic +1 oxidation state requires about 0.24 V ("volts").

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, identify the following about animals fighting in human wars.
answers_sanitized: Crimean War [or The War in the Crimea]
Lydians [or Sparda; or Maeonia; or Maeonians; accept Lydia]
Battle of the Little Bighorn [or Battle of the Greasy Grass; prompt on Custer's Last Stand]
parts: A female tortoise named Timothy who served as the mascot to several Royal Navy vessels is sometimes considered to be the oldest survivor of this war. Britain and France joined this war following a naval battle at Sinope ("SYE-noh-pee").
A king of these people named Alyattes employed war dogs to expel the Cimmerians from Asia Minor in the 6th century BCE. Their capital was Sardis.
A horse named Comanche was the only survivor of the detachment led by General George Custer at this 1876 battle, which was a notable victory for the Lakota under Sitting Bull and Crazy Horse.
